text.p: The following are leading domestic stories in Portuguese newspapers.

- The Portuguese government may have to pay electricity company EDP 20 billion escudos in compensation if rock carvings found in the northern region of Foz Coa are from the Paleolithic period, because EDP will have to abandon the Foz Coa dam.
- The government is to remove four commanders from the Portuguese police force, the newspaper learned.
- The revision of the Civil Legal Code is causing disagreements between the government and judges.
- The Socialist Party (PS) cancelled a meeting called for today due to internal squabbling.
- EDP-Electricidade de Portugal reduced to five from seven the number of its directors. Sources in the sector called their departures "political cleansing".
- Economy Minister Augusto Mateus foresees that by the end of January 1997 40,000 to 45,000 further applications will have been received from companies seeking to pay their tax debts.
- Dutch Finance Minister Gerrit Zalm said that he doubted that Portugal would be amongst European Union countries to launch the single currency in 1999.
- Banco Portugues de Investimento (BPI) may take a 25 percent stake of battery manufacturer Autosil.
- Insurance company Imperio expects to quadruple its net results by the end of 1998 to more than four billion escudos, its president Jaime de Almeida told the paper.
